issueDTO.title: Bug: Jupyter tab not showing input commands
issueDTO.description:
## Summary

The Jupyter tab in OpenHands was not displaying input commands, only showing outputs. This made the Jupyter experience appear broken or incomplete, as users could see the results of IPython commands but not the commands themselves.

## Environment

- **OpenHands Version**: Latest (main branch)
- **Runtime**: All runtimes with Jupyter support
- **Browser**: All browsers
- **Affected Component**: Frontend Jupyter tab

## Bug Description

### Expected Behavior
The Jupyter tab should display both:
1. Input commands (the Python code being executed)
2. Output results (the execution results)

### Actual Behavior
The Jupyter tab only displayed:
1. ??? Input commands: Missing
2. ??? Output results: Working correctly

### Impact
- Users couldn't see what commands were being executed
- Jupyter tab appeared broken or non-functional
- Poor user experience for data analysis workflows
- Made it difficult to understand the agent's Python code execution

## Root Cause

The issue was in the frontend action handling logic in `frontend/src/services/actions.ts`. The system was missing handling for `RUN_IPYTHON` actions to add input to the Jupyter state.

**Missing Code:**
```typescript
if (message.action === ActionType.RUN_IPYTHON) {
  store.dispatch(appendJupyterInput(message.args.code));
}
```

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Start OpenHands with Jupyter enabled
2. Ask an agent to run Python code (e.g., "Create a simple plot using matplotlib")
3. Navigate to the Jupyter tab
4. Observe that only outputs are shown, not the input commands

## Fix

Fixed in PR #9533

## Labels

- bug
- frontend
- jupyter
- good first issue
comments: Hi, I'd like to take this on. Could you please assign it to me?
Hi @mirchez we actually already have a PR open for this one but feel free to take another one!

repository.description: 🙌 OpenHands: Code Less, Make More

summary.validationOrRequirement: The Jupyter tab should display both input commands and output results.
summary.attemptedFixes: Fixed in PR #9533
summary.otherNotes: The issue was in the frontend action handling logic in frontend/src/services/actions.ts. The system was missing handling for RUN_IPYTHON actions to add input to the Jupyter state.

issueDTO.title: [Good First Issue] [RISCV64]: Implement CPU plugin just-in-time emitter for Tanh operation
issueDTO.description:
### Context

[JIT Emitters](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/emitters/README.md) are part of code generation feature (a.k.a. tensor compiler) that automatically produces highly-efficient optimized fused subgraph binary code. Each emitter implements specific operation from low level OpenVINO dialect.

### Prerequisites
Due to limited resources, cross compilation is preferred option now for building OpenVINO targeting RISC-V development boards. Please see the documentation ["Cross compile OpenVINO??? Runtime for RISCV64 systems"](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/docs/dev/build_riscv64.md) for more details. For this work, you need to build [`xuantie-gnu-toolchain`](https://github.com/XUANTIE-RV/) or [`riscv-gnu-toolchain`](https://github.com/riscv-collab/riscv-gnu-toolchain.git) with `QEMU` support for emulation. So you don't need to have RISC-V development board even to contribute to OpenVINO for these platforms 😃 

### What needs to be done?

* Create `fp32` [Tanh](https://docs.openvino.ai/2025/documentation/openvino-ir-format/operation-sets/operation-specs/arithmetic/tanh-1.html) operation [JIT Emitter](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/emitters/plugin/riscv64/jit_eltwise_emitters.hpp) for RISCV64 platform with RVV1.0 support. Use OpenVINO [CPU plugin JIT emitters](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/emitters/README.md) documentation and [RISC-V "V" Vector Extension](https://github.com/riscvarchive/riscv-v-spec/releases/tag/v1.0) documentation for details.
* Support your implemented JIT Emitter in the [JIT Executor](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/4ebe493140b90cbaaa68e2c71fe8e1dbd7461822/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/nodes/eltwise.cpp#L805).
* Modify [RISCV64 kernel](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/4ebe493140b90cbaaa68e2c71fe8e1dbd7461822/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/nodes/kernels/riscv64/jit_uni_eltwise_generic.hpp#L19) (in both places: [create_eltwise_emitter](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/4ebe493140b90cbaaa68e2c71fe8e1dbd7461822/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/nodes/kernels/riscv64/jit_uni_eltwise_generic.cpp#L401) and [get_supported_precisions](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/4ebe493140b90cbaaa68e2c71fe8e1dbd7461822/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/nodes/kernels/riscv64/jit_uni_eltwise_generic.cpp#L528)) to apply developed JIT emitter.

Before emitter implementation, please, modify tests to be sure that developed functionality is covered by test:
 * Add `jit` kernel check in [activation](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/0a177ff48a7197bee7eeb08f4e81b9d0ce8db271/src/plugins/intel_cpu/tests/functional/custom/single_layer_tests/classes/activation.cpp#L229) test, the test must fail.
* If test doesn't fail then add supported operation in [CPU activation test instantiation](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/0a177ff48a7197bee7eeb08f4e81b9d0ce8db271/src/plugins/intel_cpu/tests/functional/custom/single_layer_tests/classes/activation.cpp#L263) if it's absent.

### Tests
Tests are disabled in default build, so ensure to add `-DENABLE_TESTS=ON` into cmake command during the project configuration.

[GoogleTest](https://github.com/google/googletest) is used for testing. CPU functional test target is [ov_cpu_func_tests](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/tree/master/src/plugins/intel_cpu/tests/functional). You can use `GoogleTest` filter:
```sh
# If you use xuantie-gnu-toolchain:
<xuantie_install_path>/bin/qemu-riscv64 -cpu rv64,x-v=true,vext_spec=v1.0 ./bin/[platform]/[build_type]/ov_cpu_func_tests --gtest_filter="*smoke*Activation*Tanh*"

# If you use riscv-gnu-toolchain:
<riscv_install_path>/bin/qemu-riscv64 -cpu rv64,v=true,vext_spec=v1.0 ./bin/[platform]/[build_type]/ov_cpu_func_tests --gtest_filter="*smoke*Activation*Tanh*"
```

### Example Pull Requests

* [Abs](https://docs.openvino.ai/2025/documentation/openvino-ir-format/operation-sets/operation-specs/arithmetic/abs-1.html) operation: https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/pull/30218


### Resources

- [Contribution guide - start here!](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [What is OpenVINO?](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino#what-is-openvino-toolkit)
- [CPU plugin JIT emitters](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/src/plugins/intel_cpu/src/emitters/README.md)
- [Blog post on contributing to OpenVINO](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- [User documentation](https://docs.openvino.ai/)
- [Intel DevHub Discord channel](https://discord.gg/7pVRxUwdWG) - engage in discussions, ask questions and talk to OpenVINO developers
- [How to link your Pull Request to an issue](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue#manually-linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue-using-the-pull-request-sidebar)
-  ["Cross compile OpenVINO??? Runtime for RISCV64 systems"](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/blob/master/docs/dev/build_riscv64.md)
- [RISC-V "V" Vector Extension](https://github.com/riscvarchive/riscv-v-spec/releases/tag/v1.0)


### Contact points

@a-sidorova
comments:
Hi @a-sidorova!
Can I work on this?

issueDTO.title: New `/p` subcommands for better pattern search
issueDTO.description:
Currently, `/p` command is 1) undocumented, along with the function `rz_search_pattern()` 2) is limited.

Idea is to expand `/p` command with multiple subcommands that will correspond to pattern generation commands - `pp`.
Thus, each `pp` subcommand, e.g. `ppd` should have a search sibling, e.g. `/pd` for search De Bruijn patterns, and so on.

Current `/p` command could become `/pr` or something like that, to indicate that it is a generic search for any repeating pattern.

```
[0x100000960]> pp?
Usage: pp<?>   # Print patterns
???pp0 [<len>] # Print buffer filled with zeroes
???pp1 [<len>] # Print incremental byte pattern (honor lower bits of current address and block size)
???pp2 [<len>] # Print incremental word pattern
???pp4 [<len>] # Print incremental dword pattern
???pp8 [<len>] # Print incremental qword pattern
???ppa [<len>] # Print Latin alphabet pattern
???ppd [<len>] # Print De Brujin pattern
???ppf [<len>] # Print buffer filled with 0xFF
???ppn [<len>] # Print numeric pin pattern
```
comments:
> Current /p command could become /p. or something like that, to indicate that it reads pattern from the current seek.

That's not what `/p` currently does. I should have made a better example, didn't think it could be misinterpreted this way.

Better description for current `/p n` would be "search n byte patterns which show up in binary  more than once". 

` /p 3` on "ABCFABCGIIABC" would return positions for "ABC", but it would also do the same when run on "xyzABCFABCGIIABC". 

In case of `/p 3` run on "mxyzabckabcxyzxyz" it woud report "xyz" 3 positions, "abc" 2 positions because both of them can be found more than once. Current seek doesn't matter.


Also I am not sure if rest of your suggestion makes sense. The word pattern is a bit overloaded here. Just because 2 command descriptions contain word "pattern" doesn't mean they are related or that the type of patterns are in any way related.

Some of the `pp` patterns like pp0 and ppf which make some sense to search are already better covered by `/x` and `/xr`  .

`pp8 n` prints n words each incremented by one starting with current seek position (not the content) . `pp1` -`pp4` doe the same just limiting to lower 1-4 address bytes of current seek position. What do you expect to be searched ? Whole ascending number sequence or any of the words?

`ppd` assuming it refers to de Brujin  sequence and there aren't multiple things named after him, why would you want to search for it in an executable. In specific situations it's useful strategy for trying every combination in less steps by overlaping the values, but searching for the pattern itself in binary makes little sense to me. Searching if executable contains hard coded (in the target executable)  de Brujin sequence, is no better than having a dedicated search command for Fibonacci sequence or nth digit of pi.

As  side note, seems like the `ppd` command currently itself is kind of buggy. `ppd 2` currently prints `4141` which is not a proper de Brujin sequence.  Based on what it prints for larger values I guess that `ppd n` prints "the first n bytes in B([A-Za-z], 3) encoded as ascii bytes". Maybe it's B(A-Za-z, 2) or something similar, hard to tell precisely by just eyeballing it. Partial de Brujin sequence has little value, and not being able to choose alphabet size or word length as makes the current implementation of command useless.

Having search commands for `ppa` and `ppn` also seems questionable due to the same reasons as de Brujin sequence.

The implementation of them also seem kind of buggy.

`ppn` starts printing 4 digit codes in  LSB order from 0-99 (0000-9900) then jumps back to 0000 0000  1000-9000 (repeated twice in addition to being at the start of sequence)  and after a while it finally starts setting 3rd digit to non 0 values. 

`ppa` is similar (including repetition) but for 4 character (A-Za-z) words. Why 4 characters exactly, why fixed "A-Za-z", what is the actual logic behind the order?

Most of my observations above are based on slightly outdated rizin version.


The way I look at most of the `pp` commands having them for printing those sequences are more or of swiss army knife style utilities. Occasionally they might be useful for something and it's nice to have a builtin command for generating them instead of having lookup some online tool or copy pasting snippet from stack overflow. But how you actually use the output of them is very situation specific.

> Better description for current /p n would be "search n byte patterns which show up in binary more than once".

Thanks, fixed in the description.

> ppd assuming it refers to de Brujin sequence and there aren't multiple things named after him, why would you want to search for it in an executable. In specific situations it's useful strategy for trying every combination in less steps by overlaping the values, but searching for the pattern itself in binary makes little sense to me. Searching if executable contains hard coded (in the target executable) de Brujin sequence, is no better than having a dedicated search command for Fibonacci sequence or nth digit of pi.

Not whole patterns and not the executable. One of the valid scenarios - using Rizin to open memory dumps or coredumps, where *parts* of De Bruijn pattern could be located.

issueDTO.title: Accept multiline comments in body
issueDTO.description:
The body of the commit message should accept multiline comments, i.e. paragraphs. According to commitizen/cz-cli#398, the body type should be `editor`,  instead of `input`. I can provide a PR if needed.

https://github.com/digitalroute/cz-conventional-changelog-for-jira/blob/40370f1f87659a326e2fc8ca9a7ecedd515b1c2c/engine.js#L159-L165
comments:
Hi! Thanks for creating this issue!

My interpretation of that issue is that it is possible to use an `editor` in your own fork, but that `cz-cli` has decided to not do it. I have concerns with introducing an editor input instead of a one-line input.

I agree with you that it's much easier to create nice commit messages in a much better format. I do however think there are some very large drawbacks. Firstly the default editor is vim, which scares a large portion of new developers. I think this library should be a helpful tool _especially_ for new developers. Secondly, I think it's a bit distracting to get redirected into some other interface (for all developers who have configured vs code as their default editor).

In my experience, most commit messages are short enough to be one line, and the few messages that I want to have longer, I write using GitKraken or in my favorite editor by just running `git commit`. I don't think we should optimize for the infrequent use case of having to write long commit messages when the majority of commit messages are short and where this change would hurt that majority of use cases.

With that said, I do agree that I would want to be able to write multiline commits with this tool as well (even though it's more of a nice to have). And it can also be seen as a motivator to write better and longer commit messages.

I looked into creating my own inquirer prompt that would somehow allow multiline inputs but still stay in the same terminal context. We don't want to reinvent the wheel by creating a new fully-fledged editor but what we could do is allow you to write one line at a time. When you have written a line and press enter you get a new input. If you leave it empty we go to the next prompt but as long as you keep writing stuff you will get new inputs. This wouldn't allow you to go back and delete or change your commit message but maybe that's fine.

What do you think about all of this?

I understand your concerns, and thanks for the detailed response. I did not realize that this is a feature not provided in `cz-cli` either. I do think that it is a great addition though, since I frequently write multi-line comments. I believe commits should be a kind of documentation, and having one-liner descriptions makes it harder.

Your suggestion sounds like a nice compromise. I think that a hint of that behavior would help a lot, since an empty line acting as an end is not that intuitive.

There are some more suggestions that I would find more intuitive, although I am not sure if they are technically feasible. The discussion in `cz-cli` mentioned potentially parsing `\n` or `\r\n` sequences. However, I find using `Shift + Enter` is a common shortcut in the web when entering new lines in fields that are submitted on `Enter`. If the terminal would allow such handling, I think it would be best.

Yeah, actually that is a great suggestion! If you can detect `Shift + Enter` I think that is the best. It is easy to add a small hint saying `(press Shift + Enter for a new line)`. I think the easiest implementation is to create a custom prompt.

The greatest challenge is probably how to support going back to previous lines and delete stuff, but maybe you don't have to support that.
Indeed it might be out of this scope deleting previous lines, although I do think that it might be possible with some trickery. However, this is still just an extra "nice to have".
we really need multilines commit, any news?

summary.otherNotes: The issue is about accepting multiline comments in the body of the commit message, with the author suggesting a custom prompt to achieve this. The discussion involves concerns about introducing an editor input, default editor being vim, and the need for a compromise.

issueDTO.title: [Bug] Demo dubbo-samples-triple-http3 consumer print org.apache.dubbo.rpc.StatusRpcException: CANCELLED
issueDTO.description:
### Pre-check

- [x] I am sure that all the content I provide is in English.


### Search before asking

- [x] I had searched in the [issues](https://github.com/apache/dubbo/issues?q=is%3Aissue) and found no similar issues.


### Apache Dubbo Component

Java Samples (apache/dubbo-samples)

### Dubbo Version

dubbo 3.3.1 jdk 17 windows/mac/centos7.9

### Steps to reproduce this issue

modify demo dubbo-samples-triple-http3  GreeterServiceImpl to this

`    @Override
    public HelloReply sayHello(HelloRequest request) {
        LOGGER.info("Received sayHello request: {}", request.getName());
        StringBuffer finalString = new StringBuffer();
        IntStream.range(0,10000).forEach(
              i->  finalString.append("Hello")
        );
        return toReply(finalString + request.getName());
    }
`

then run test
`   @Test
    public void sayHello() {
        HelloReply reply = greeterService.sayHello(buildRequest("world"));
        Assert.assertEquals("Hello world", reply.getMessage());
    }`


issueDTO.title: [Feature]: Support for `CREATE` and `USAGE` grants on database schemas
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing issue already for this feature request/idea?

- [x] I have searched for an existing issue, and could not find anything. I believe this is a new feature request to be evaluated.

### What problem is this feature going to solve? Why should it be added?

Right now, the `Database` CRD only manages the `owner` of the schema.

PostgreSQL provides two privileges as part of the `GRANT` command on schemas: `CREATE` and `GRANT`. See ["SQL Grant"](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-grant.html).

Users are now using the post initialization scripts for this, making it imperative, one-off and thus fragile.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Providing usage permissions on managed schema objects as part of the `Database` CRD.

The `GRANT` SQL command in Postgres has the following syntax:

```sql
GRANT { { CREATE | USAGE } [, ...] | ALL [ PRIVILEGES ] }
    ON SCHEMA schema_name [, ...]
    TO role_specification [, ...] [ WITH GRANT OPTION ]
    [ GRANTED BY role_specification ]
```

Both `GRANTED BY` and `WITH GRANT OPTION` are not suitable for a declarative environment typical of CloudNativePG, so we will focus only on `CREATE` and `USAGE`.

A possible implementation could be:

```yaml
# ...
spec:
  schemas:
  - name: app
    owner: app
    create:
    - name: angus
      type: grant
    - name: brian
      type: revoke
    usage:
    - name: angus
      type: grant
    - name: brian
      type: grant
# ...
```

The default `type` is `grant`.

For example, the above will check that `angus` hasn't got yet the `create` privilege for the `app` database and run the required `GRANT CREATE ON app TO angus`. Similarly, if `brian` has `create` usage on the same `app` schema, it will run `REVOKE CREATE ON app FROM angus`.

See: [`REVOKE`](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-revoke.html).

Please feel free to change the above proposal if you have a better idea.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

We could do nothing, and delegate this operation to another tool.

However, I personally think that this is a good responsibility for the `schema` management feature in the `Database` CRD.

### Additional context

N/A

### Backport?

No

### Are you willing to actively contribute to this feature?

Yes

### Code of Conduct

- [x] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct
comments: This could actually be a project for a future mentorship program.

issueDTO.title: Custom traits need to be added to the cloning whitelist
issueDTO.description:
## Description
Just a small info for you.
Components from custom character traits (or any other fork specific components you have that should be copied upon cloning) need to be whitelisted in 
`Resources/Prototypes/Entities/Mobs/Player/clone.yml`
to be copied correctly to the paradox clone or in cloning pods. This only works for simple components that can be shallow copied. Everything more complex like `SpeechComponent` needs a subscription to `CloningEvent` to handle copying the needed datafields over.

**Reproduction**
Clone someone with a custom trait that is not from upstream. For easy testing in the dev environment you can simply use the "random clone spawner" in the spawn menu.
comments:
Thanks

Should be illeism and hypophonia.
The `RaisedByX` ones as well. Since those modify the `SpeechComponent` you will need to do a `CloningEvent` subscription for them.

Was most of the way before writing a specific bug report before noticing this.  Encountered the issue with the "Illiesm" speech trait with a paradox clone.

## Description
Paradox clones do not get the "Illeism" speech trait if the original has the trait.  This allows the two characters to be easily distinguished by asking both players to type "I" and "Me."  The clone will not have the words converted, and is thus easily found out.  

**Reproduction**
Create character with Illeism trait.  
Create paradox clone of character.  
Speak "I" or "Me" as paradox clone.

summary.attemptedFixes: The issue was almost fixed before a specific bug report was written, and the author encountered the issue with the 'Illeism' speech trait in a paradox clone.
summary.otherNotes: Custom character traits need to be whitelisted in `Resources/Prototypes/Entities/Mobs/Player/clone.yml` for correct copying in paradox clones or cloning pods. Complex components like `SpeechComponent` require a subscription to `CloningEvent` for datafield copying.

issueDTO.title: Implement mgp object serialization
issueDTO.description: It would be useful if all objects from [`mgp`](https://github.com/memgraph/memgraph/blob/master/include/mgp.py) are `JSON` serializable, that is, that there is some kind of method that returns Python `Dict` of `mgp` objects. For example, when I'm writing a [query module for database export](https://github.com/memgraph/mage/pull/100), I'm actually creating a `JSON` file with a list of nodes and relationships. Therefore, I have to reach every label, property, etc. of each `Vertex` and `Edge`. I would like to be able to just add properties as a list to my properties key, but then `mgp.Vertex.properties` is not `JSON` serializable. I solved this by going through all properties and creating new dictionary, but I think that the right place for this code would be inside mgp and not query module. Since we're going to create new utility modules similar to the export one, this feature may come in handy.
comments:
Since we added the support for functions, there are more places where this type of functionality can fit:
* [Mage](https://github.com/memgraph/mage) because if this is implemented as a function, it could be used as a part of any expression
* As a ["built-in" Memgraph function](https://github.com/memgraph/memgraph/blob/master/src/query/interpret/awesome_memgraph_functions.hpp)

repository.description: Open-source graph database, tuned for dynamic analytics environments. Easy to adopt, scale and own.
repository.name: memgraph

summary.main: Implement a method to serialize mgp objects to JSON, making it possible to easily serialize objects like Vertex and Edge.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The mgp objects should be JSON serializable, allowing for easy serialization of objects like Vertex and Edge.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author solved the issue by manually going through all properties and creating a new dictionary, but believes this should be implemented inside mgp and not query module.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the query module for database export and the need to serialize mgp objects to JSON. It's considered a good first issue with a medium effort level and a lower priority.

issueDTO.title: Use constraints as indices if possible
comments: @Josipmrden, did we implement this? I think so. Can you link the PRs implementing this and close this issue?

Memgraph's current architecture creates a skip list for each uniqueness constraint and index.

Typically, you would have the index on uniqueness constraint. This presents a 2x memory reduction on the total number of nodes:

10 milion nodes with application ID = 1GB (approximately)
10 milion nodes with index on application ID = 2 GB (approximately)
10 milion nodes with a constraint on the application ID = 3GB (approximately)
Scaling this by a factor of 10:
100M nodes = 10GB
100M nodes + index = 20GB
100M nodes + index + constraint = 30GB
Scaling this  by a factor of 10
1B = 100GB
1B nodes + index = 200GB
1B  nodes + index + constraint = 300GB

Previous attempts: https://github.com/memgraph/memgraph/pull/1356

summary.otherNotes: Memgraph's current architecture creates a skip list for each uniqueness constraint and index. Typically, you would have the index on uniqueness constraint. This presents a 2x memory reduction on the total number of nodes.

issueDTO.title: Add IS NOT NULL to query builder
issueDTO.description:
Below should work:
```
Python: `match().node(variable='n').to().node(variable='m').where(item='n.name', operator=Operator.IS_NOT_NULL).return_()`
Cypher: `MATCH (n)-[]->(m) WHERE n.name IS NOT NULL RETURN *;`
```

Currently, there is no operator IS_NOT_NULL in Operator Enum and where() necessarily requires three arguments (literal or expression as third), while in this case there would be 2 args)
comments: I also have a need for this - currently unable to do the query I want in the query builder without it

issueDTO.title: Running the DFS algorithm in Memgraph

As the default relationship traversal algorithm is DFS, users could be confused when trying to switch between BFS and DFS.
It would be useful to include `dfs` as an explicit option just like `bfs` even though it wouldn't result in any changes in the underlying implementation. For example:
```
MATCH (a {id: 723})-[edge_list:Type *dfs..10]-(b {id: 882}) RETURN *;
```

issueDTO.title: Fix min int value throws error
issueDTO.description:
**Memgraph version**
2.3.1

**Environment**
Windows, Docker, Bolt, PHP Bolt library

**Describe the bug**
When I run query with min int value I get error:
Integer literal exceeds 64 bits. (Memgraph.ClientError.MemgraphError.MemgraphError)

Min int value on x64 is -9223372036854775808

**To Reproduce**
1. Run query `RETURN $i` over bolt protocol with min int value as parameter.

**Expected behavior**
I expect to get min int value instead of error.
comments:
I've tried to recreate the issue with `pymgclient` -> https://youtu.be/tiSP255Ukx0?t=3971
The code is:
```
import mgclient
conn = mgclient.connect(host='127.0.0.1', port=7687)
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("RETURN $i;", {'i': -9223372036854775808})
row = cursor.fetchone()
print(row)
```
Python client seems to return a valid result.

@stefanak-michal could you please double-check that the issue is not somewhere inside the PHP Bolt library?
I have put this task into the backlog.

```
MATCH path = (child:Node{id:100})<-[:PARENT*]-(root:Node)
```

issueDTO.title: Implement a COLLECT subquery that correctly handles null values
issueDTO.description:
Aggregation function `collect(t.id, p.id);` automatically ignores null values and doesn't add them to the list; the returned collection does not contain any nulls. 

**Feature request:** Implement COLLECT subquery which will not remove null values automatically.
https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/current/subqueries/collect/#collect-differentiation

Example dataset and queries:
```
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '1'})-[:ASSIGNED_TO]->(:Person {id:'1'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '2'})-[:ASSIGNED_TO]->(:Person {id:'2'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '3'})-[:ASSIGNED_TO]->(:Person {id:'3'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '4'})
CREATE (:project {id: '1'})-[:HAS]->(:Task {id: '5'})

//running the following query correctly fills out non-assigned tasks with null for a person:
MATCH (:project {id: '1'})--(t:Task)
OPTIONAL MATCH (t)-[:ASSIGNED_TO]-(p:Person)
RETURN t.id, p.id;

//running the collect function doesn't return the tasks with a null person:
MATCH (:project {id: '1'})--(t:Task)
OPTIONAL MATCH (t)-[:ASSIGNED_TO]-(p:Person)
RETURN collect(t.id, p.id);

//WORKAROUND: forcing the person id into a list includes the null values:
MATCH (:project {id: '1'})--(t:Task)
OPTIONAL MATCH (t)-[:ASSIGNED_TO]-(p:Person)
RETURN collect(t.id, [p.id]);
```
comments: A good way to start addressing this issue might be to review the `Aggregate` implementation in `operator.hpp` and `operator.cpp` to see how Memgraph handles null values. I suggest checking the `ProcessAll` and `ProcessOne` functions.
This is very important feature that doesn't seem to work. please fix it.

repository.description: Open-source graph database, tuned for dynamic analytics environments. Easy to adopt, scale and own.
repository.name: memgraph

summary.main: Implement a COLLECT subquery that correctly handles null values, allowing null values to be included in the returned collection.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Implement COLLECT subquery which will not remove null values automatically, as per the documentation at https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/current/subqueries/collect/#collect-differentiation.
summary.attemptedFixes: The workaround is to force the person id into a list, which includes null values.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the implementation of the COLLECT subquery in Cypher, specifically handling null values. The workaround is to force the person id into a list, which includes null values.

issueDTO.title: Hide IA cover upload when cover from IA is already uploaded
issueDTO.description:
### Feature Request

### Problem / Opportunity
<!-- Describe: What is the problem this proposal addresses & for which audience(s)? -->
Right now when someone goes to a book such as [this](https://openlibrary.org/books/OL59004677M/Harry_Potter_and_The_Goblet_of_Fire_4) and clicks "Manage covers" one of the options they're presented with is "Or, use the the cover from Internet Archive".

@cdrini noticed that quite often people are clicking that button and uploading a cover when that cover is already uploaded.

As such, we should make it so the IA option is hidden if the cover from IA is already uploaded to that edition.

@cdrini please update/elaborate this issue as needed.

comments:
Hi @RayBB, could I work on this issue?

It looks like the html that renders the "manage covers" options already checks if the book is an edition and a part of internet archive before adding the IA cover option:

https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/blob/12cfbb24038a8bd44a9e47007d490d89a443f59d/openlibrary/templates/covers/add.html#L83-L95

I believe all covers uploaded from IA have a description in the history that is "//covers.openlibrary.org/b/id/XXX.jpg" and every other method has the description "Update covers". This means the issue could be resolved if there is a check added to verify:

1. The most recent cover change is not "Update covers" and
2. The IA change description is not present in the history logs

I still have work to do to understand the best way to look through the history logs and to determine the best location for this check (i.e. in the add.html file above with the existing checks or possibly somewhere else).
Hi @emggeorge that's a really great description of what the first steps will look like! Please go ahead and give it a shot and let me know if you need help!

issueDTO.title: [Content] Insufficient text-to-background contrast
issueDTO.description: ### Title [Content] Insufficient text-to-background contrast ### Description The text color used in the following element has insufficient contrast with its background color. This results in very low readability, especially for users with low vision or color vision deficiencies. According to WCAG 2.2 Level AA, normal text must have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, and large text (over 18 pt or 14 pt bold) must meet 3:1. The detected text on the page does not satisfy these thresholds. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. go to /tutorials/setting-up-your-environment/ 2. Locate to the following element: ``` function ``` ### Actual Behavior The word "function" is rendered in #D73A49 (a red tone) on a #F7F7F7 (light gray) background. This color combination produces a contrast ratio that is below 4.5:1, violating WCAG 2.1 Level AA contrast requirements for normal-sized text. ### Expected Behavior Text should maintain sufficient color contrast against its background to ensure readability. For normal-size text, the minimum ratio is 4.5:1; for large text (over 18pt or 14pt bold), 3:1. The color combination used should meet or exceed these thresholds. ### Environments _No response_ ### Suggested Fix Increase the contrast between the foreground (text) color and the background color. ### Reference WCAG: * [Success Criterion 1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum)](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#contrast-minimum) WCAG-T: * [G18: Ensuring that a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 exists between text (and images of text) and background behind the text](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/general/G18) * [G145: Ensuring that a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 exists between text (and images of text) and background behind the text](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/general/G145) ### What is your operating system? None ### Web browser and version _No response_
comments: I???m updating my original comment after working on this quite a bit today but hitting a wall. It seems Shiki is controlling the CSS, and no amount of !important overrides work. I also tried manipulating Shiki???s inline styles by importing codeToHtml and transformers in .astro files, but colors still don???t change in development mode. Any suggestions are more than welcome. I took a plunge in but I'm very new to github.

issueDTO.title: Make integer suffix definition stricter
issueDTO.description:
ISPC has too frivolous definition for integer suffixes in parser:
`INT_NUMBER (([0-9]+)|(0[xX][0-9a-fA-F]+)|(0b[01]+))[uUlL]*[kMG]?[uUlL]*` ([link](https://github.com/ispc/ispc/blob/fd297fa67ce52ce7d46da137ab3d2281a26d79c7/src/lex.ll#L370))

It has the following problems:
1. it doesn't limit the number of occurrences of [uUlL] symbols, for example this appears legal: `1uUuUlllLLllLLuUu` ([godbolt link](https://godbolt.org/z/Psb8hMbcd))
2. value modification suffix (i.e. [kMG]) may go after type modification suffix. This seems illogical to me and gives too much freedom where it's not needed.
3. Unlike C/C++ it allows `lL` and `Ll` suffixes (i.e. the mix of lower and upper case "L" to form a 'LL' suffix). Only `ll` and `LL` should be allowed.

repository.description: Intel?? Implicit SPMD Program Compiler
repository.name: ispc

summary.main: Make the integer suffix definition stricter to prevent frivolous definitions and ensure correct parsing.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The integer suffix definition should limit the number of occurrences of [uUlL] symbols, and value modification suffix should not go after type modification suffix. Only 'll' and 'LL' should be allowed.
summary.otherNotes: The issue description includes a link to the parser definition in lex.ll file and also provides examples of problematic cases, including godbolt link.

issueDTO.title: Implement mask support
issueDTO.description: Support masks during training.
comments:
would love to see this one implemented as well. I usually generate masks for use with colmap, not to increase precision, but to reduce memory consumption, so I can process a larger dataset at a given time.

if we were to feed images masked, (like object in the middle, and surroundings masked) would it work for gaussian splatting?

best regards,
-c.a.

I revisited this. If it can be externally implemented, for example by providing masked images, there the black parts are transparents and white parts image itself.  So if masks can be externally applied to images and these images fed into gsplatcuda, me might not need to implement this feature in software, in the name of not making it bloated and focus on core functions.
You can do it this way but it is not a proper solution. To implement this, a separate mask folder is required and the masks are applied during training.

issueDTO.title: Create `fedify webfinger` command for isolated WebFinger lookups
issueDTO.description:
## Description

Create a new `fedify webfinger <handle>` command that performs isolated WebFinger lookups. While the existing `lookup` command performs comprehensive object retrieval including WebFinger, there are many cases where users only want to test WebFinger configuration. This command takes a `@user@domain` handle as an argument and outputs only the WebFinger result (JRD) in JSON format.

## Implementation Details

- Create a new `webfinger.ts` file in the CLI directory, using `lookup.ts` as a reference
- Utilize the existing `lookupWebFinger()` function from the Fedify library
- Add the new command to `mod.ts` to register it with the CLI
- Output results in clean JSON format for easy parsing
- Handle WebFinger-specific errors appropriately

## Why This Is a Good First Issue

- **Independent feature**: Add new functionality without modifying existing code
- **Learn structure**: Experience the complete process of adding a new CLI command
- **Code reuse**: Great example of leveraging existing Fedify library functions
- **Focused scope**: Single-purpose command with clear input/output expectations

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Create `fedify webfinger <handle>` command
- [ ] Accept `@user@domain` format handles as input
- [ ] Output WebFinger JRD results in JSON format
- [ ] Handle invalid handles and WebFinger lookup failures gracefully
- [ ] Register the command in the CLI module system
- [ ] Add appropriate help text and usage examples

## Files to Create/Modify

- `cli/webfinger.ts` - New command implementation
- `cli/mod.ts` - Register the new command

## Example Usage

```bash
fedify webfinger @user@example.com
fedify webfinger @mastodon@mastodon.social
```

repository.name: fedify

issueDTO.title: [Feature]: Using xcframework instead of using dylib
issueDTO.description:
### Background & Description

I noticed that the LLama.cpp has compiled the xcframework library for all Apple devices/platforms, by using the xcframework will brings those benefits:

- Currently the only support Apple devices/platforms is macOS, the xcframework will add the support of iOS, visionOS, tvOS etc.
- Using the .dylib in macOS, since the library is not signed, the OS will block the library loading, which is annoying 
- The cross-platform .Net solutions such as MAUI, Unity3D, will be easily to integration

### API & Usage

_No response_

### How to implement

_No response_
comments:
Sounds good, are you interested in putting together a PR for this?

The first steps would be:
1. Modify the build script to produce the correct files ([here](https://github.com/SciSharp/LLamaSharp/blob/master/.github/workflows/compile.yml#L447)). We're using the llama.cpp cmake, so you would probably just need to adjust some compiler flags.
2. Modify the file uploads ([here](https://github.com/SciSharp/LLamaSharp/blob/master/.github/workflows/compile.yml#L478)) to the correct extension
3. Package the new files ([here](https://github.com/SciSharp/LLamaSharp/blob/master/.github/workflows/compile.yml#L681))

I found that the llama.cpp project using a [custom shell script](https://github.com/ggml-org/llama.cpp/blob/master/build-xcframework.sh) to build xcframework, so it may need more time to complete the migration.

I'll try and see what can I do for this project.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity. If no further activity occurs, it will be closed in 7 days.

repository.description: A C#/.NET library to run LLM (🦙LLaMA/LLaVA) on your local device efficiently.
repository.name: LLamaSharp

summary.main: The main goal is to migrate from using dylib to using xcframework, which will add support for multiple Apple platforms and make it easier to integrate with cross-platform solutions.

summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests modifying the build script, file uploads, and packaging the new files, and mentions that the llama.cpp project uses a custom shell script to build xcframework.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about migrating from dylib to xcframework, which will add support for iOS, watchOS, tvOS, etc., and will make it easier to integrate with cross-platform .Net solutions like MAUI and Unity3D.

issueDTO.title: time.sleep(-1.0) causes panic
issueDTO.description:
## Summary
https://github.com/RustPython/RustPython/pull/5892/files#r2183174081
```
import time
time.sleep(-1)
```

## Expected
raise exception
<!-- What's the expected result? Using ``` ``` block is preferred for text. -->

## Actual
panic
<!-- What's the actual result? Using ``` ``` block is preferred for text. -->

## Python Documentation

<!-- If applicable. -->
comments:
**Hi, can I take up this issue?**

I'm planning to modify the `time.sleep()` implementation to safely handle:

- Negative values 

**Proposed solution:**

- Modify the dur type to f64 insted of Duration
- Validate the `f64` input before conversion  
- Raise a `ValueError` if the input is invalid
- For valid values, use `Duration::from_secs_f64()`

Let me know if this approach is okay.
Yes, that's one of the possible solutions. Thanks!

repository.description: A Python Interpreter written in Rust
repository.name: RustPython

summary.main: Safely handle negative values in the `time.sleep()` implementation by raising an exception instead of panicking.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Modify the dur type to f64, validate the f64 input before conversion, and raise a ValueError if the input is invalid.
summary.attemptedFixes: Proposed solution: Modify the dur type to f64 instead of Duration, validate the f64 input before conversion, raise a ValueError if the input is invalid, and use Duration::from_secs_f64() for valid values.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about handling negative values in the `time.sleep()` implementation and expected to raise an exception instead of panicking.

issueDTO.title: update Greenwood to address all (as many) TypeScript no check comments
issueDTO.description:
### Current State

Coming out of https://github.com/ProjectEvergreen/greenwood/pull/1420, a handful of `// @ts-nocheck` comments were sprinkled around the codebase, mostly dealing with ASTs and the like.  Would be nice to give it a go and see if we can resolve as many of them as possible.

### Desired State

We'll need to add JS files to _tsconfig.json#include_
```json
{
  "include": ["./packages/*/src/types/*.d.ts", "./*.ts", "./packages/*/src/*.js"],
}
```

Then removal as many `// @ts-nocheck`  comments and fix as many issue as possible from running `yarn lint:types`, e..g
```
Found 15 errors in 9 files.

Errors  Files
     4  packages/cli/src/loader.js:9
     3  packages/init/src/index.js:35
     1  packages/init/src/util.js:28

     1  packages/plugin-adapter-netlify/src/index.js:174
     1  packages/plugin-adapter-vercel/src/index.js:149
     2  packages/plugin-css-modules/src/index.js:84

error Command failed with exit code 2.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for
```

issueDTO.title: Allow SSL Enabled External Postgres Connection
issueDTO.description:
## Problem Statement

Currently there doesn't seem to be a way to connect to an SSL enabled Postgres DB such as RDS.

## Proposed Solution

Something similar to what was available in KubeClarity: https://github.com/openclarity/openclarity/pull/513

## Alternatives Considered

I looked through the Helm Chart and Templates and don't see any way to pass the `sslMode: require` parameter or environment variable to the Postgres Driver

issueDTO.title: Add Array Node Index To current_context [Core feature]
issueDTO.description:
### Motivation: Why do you think this is important?

In many cases, the index of array node in map tasks is needed, especially if the task is programmed to output a file with a static name that will be overwritten by subsequent array nodes. the index will help add a good name to that file for example and can be backtraced.

### Goal: What should the final outcome look like, ideally?

In the returned current_context() value, a filed of node_index or a good name should be there representing the map_task index.

### Describe alternatives you've considered 

I generated a random id for each instance to distinguish which output came from which node.

###  Propose: Link/Inline OR Additional context 

_No response_

### Are you sure this issue hasn't been raised already?

- [X] Yes

### Have you read the Code of Conduct?

- [X] Yes
comments: Thank you for opening your first issue here! 🛠

To add an index to the `current_context` for array nodes, you can propose this feature enhancement in Flyte. According to [Flyte 1.9 release notes](https://flyte.org/blog/flyte-1-9-arraynode-execution-tags-new-navigation-and-more/), Flyte introduced ArrayNode map tasks, which are an evolution of the existing map tasks, providing more robust support for subtask executions. However, the current `current_context` does not include an index for array nodes.

### Proposed Solution:
1. **Motivation**: Adding an index to the `current_context` would help uniquely identify each array node's output, preventing overwrites and aiding in debugging.
2. **Goal**: Modify the `current_context` to include a `node_index` field representing the map_task index.
3. **Alternatives**: Generating random IDs for each instance, although this is less efficient and harder to trace.

Would you like more details on how to proceed with this proposal or how to implement a workaround?

### Example Code Block:
```python
from flytekit import current_context

@task
def my_task():
    ctx = current_context()
    node_index = ctx.execution_id.node_id  # Hypothetical field addition
    print(f"Node Index: {node_index}")
```

Sources:
- [Flyte 1.9 release notes](https://flyte.org/blog/flyte-1-9-arraynode-execution-tags-new-navigation-and-more/)

---
This is an AI-generated response and your feedback is appreciated! Please leave a 👍 if this is helpful and 👎 if it is not.

Mention @runllm to ask follow-up questions. See [runllm.com](https://runllm.com/) for more!

This is a simple addition, The index is already available in the environment and we should absolutely add it to the current context.

[Here is where it is declared](https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/fe879f236d0a4a5d2f6e62c2fdb6b1f21f94cdd6/flytepropeller/pkg/controller/nodes/array/execution_context.go#L11-L12)

Currently it is calculated in the array node itself - [here](https://github.com/flyteorg/flytekit/blob/efed4410266b0843f34d795cbf68b6b8f3a786ac/flytekit/bin/entrypoint.py#L56C5-L69)

We should add it to the execution parameters like other information [here](https://github.com/flyteorg/flytekit/blob/efed4410266b0843f34d795cbf68b6b8f3a786ac/flytekit/bin/entrypoint.py#L246-L273)

Follow the pattern [above](https://github.com/flyteorg/flytekit/blob/efed4410266b0843f34d795cbf68b6b8f3a786ac/flytekit/bin/entrypoint.py#L221-L230)
Please assign this task to me 🙌
Can I work on this issue?
i've assigned this issue to @Samruddhi345A, but we encourage @Atharva1723 and others interested to submit a pull request as well. the first valid pull request will be merged.

"Hello 👋, this feature request has been inactive for over 9 months. To help maintain a clean and focused backlog,  we'll be marking this issue as stale and will close the issue if we detect no activity in the next 14 days. Thank you for your contribution and understanding! 🙏"
Have raised a pr for this

issueDTO.title: `dolt diff` shows NULL values for virtual generated columns
issueDTO.description:
Repro steps:

```
create table test(pk int primary key, c0 int generated always as (pk + 1));
insert into test(pk) values (1), (2);
```

`dolt diff` will produce the following output:

```
diff --dolt a/test b/test
added table
+CREATE TABLE `test` (
+  `pk` int NOT NULL,
+  `c0` int GENERATED ALWAYS AS ((`pk` + 1)),
+  PRIMARY KEY (`pk`)
+) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_0900_bin;
+---+----+------+
|   | pk | c0   |
+---+----+------+
| + | 1  | NULL |
| + | 2  | NULL |
+---+----+------+
```

This is likely because `c0` is virtual, so the tuples in the table don't actually contain a value for it. Displaying the correct values would require evaluating the stored expression for that column, which requires a SQL engine.

As for the correct behavior here, I'm leaning towards excluding virtual generated columns from `dolt diff` entirely, since they aren't actually part of the data in the diff.
comments: hi, I would like to take this issue. could you assign it to me?

Sure! Thank you for your time!

This likely happened because Dolt previously didn't support virtual columns. And adding virtual columns complicates things.

When there are no virtual columns, there's no difference between "table rows stored on disk" and "table rows seen by the engine". But once a table has virtual columns, that distinction matters, and any code that assumes that the two are identical may get incorrect results.

In this case, it's likely that the `dolt diff` code is reading the rows directly out of storage and assuming that they match the table schema. Due to the way we store rows, adding a `NULL` to the end of a row doesn't change the bytes on disk: so for example, the row `(1, NULL)` and the row `(1,)` have the exact same bytes. So `dolt diff` is likely reading the latter and treating it like it's the former.

I think that the best solution here is to simply omit any virtual generated columns from the output, since computing the correct value for the column would be more complicated and potentially slow.

The code for the diff command is in `go/cmd/dolt/commands/diff.go`. Most of the logic for the command works by writing SQL queries against [system tables](https://docs.dolthub.com/sql-reference/version-control/dolt-system-tables). Most likely this will involve changing the behavior of the `dolt_diff()` system table function to not have columns for virtual generated columns. That table function is defined in `go/libraries/doltcore/sqle/dtablefunctions/dolt_diff_table_function.go`.

Let me know if you have any questions! There's a lot going on in these files because they interact with the SQL engine, but stepping through a sample `dolt diff` command in the debugger should help you figure out what each part is doing.
Is anyone still working on this? I'm happy to work on this or #5861, whichever y'all think would be best to do first for dolt. Thanks.

issueDTO.title: `dolt_diff_summary` system table should hide tables ignored by `dolt_ignore`
issueDTO.description: This will bring it in line with the behavior seen by `dolt diff`.
comments: It would be nice to have a simple repro in here @nicktobey.

It looks like DOLT_DIFF requires a single table name, so I'm not sure it makes sense to factor in dolt_ignore here. 

DOLT_DIFF_STAT can diff all tables (and accepts "WORKING" as an input), but only shows stats for tables that exist in both revisions. Because dolt_ignore is only supposed to filter tables that were added in the working set, it shouldn't affect the behavior of DOLT_DIFF_STAT either.

So the only function we need to consider is DOLT_DIFF_SUMMARY.  A repro would look like this:

Setup:

```sql
INSERT INTO dolt_ignore VALUE ('t', true);
CREATE TABLE t (pk int);
SELECT * FROM DOLT_DIFF_SUMMARY("HEAD", "WORKING");
```

Current output:

```
+-----------------+---------------+-----------+-------------+---------------+
| from_table_name | to_table_name | diff_type | data_change | schema_change |
+-----------------+---------------+-----------+-------------+---------------+
|                 | t             | added     | false       | true          |
+-----------------+---------------+-----------+-------------+---------------+
```

Expected output:

```
Empty set
```
Is that fine if I take this issue to work on?

summary.attemptedFixes: It is unclear if any fixes have been attempted or blockers encountered.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the `dolt_diff_summary` system table hiding tables ignored by `dolt_ignore`, aligning with the behavior of `dolt diff`. The comment suggests considering only `DOLT_DIFF_SUMMARY` function and provides a reproducible example with setup and expected output.

issueDTO.title: Implement whisper.cpp
issueDTO.description:
If there is a way to auto-detect between language model files and asr model files. We should do that, or if that's not possible we should just use a runtime flag, so some options for the runtime flag would be:

```
ramalama --runtime vllm
ramalama --runtime llama.cpp
ramalama --runtime whisper.cpp
```
comments:
We added a basic version of whisper.cpp to the Container image here:

https://github.com/containers/ramalama/pull/49
Can this be closed?  Do we have this functionality now?
There's still more work for both `--runtime whisper.cpp` and `--runtime vllm` ... It can be tracked under this issue or somewhere else.

What do you see an example command-line looking like here?  I've toyed a bit with whisper.cpp and find its use to be very different than launching a gradio server or a chat instance.  AFAICT, you're usually calling the main executable with an argument for the model and one or more additional arguments describing the file to transcribe and options.

How would you feel about, as an alternative, dropping users into a [containerized] shell with access to input/output/model volumes and possibly some helper scripts to accomplish simple tasks?  So, perhaps, ```ramalama run --runtime whisper.cpp ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin``` gets you a bash prompt with a motd saying ```type 'transcribe /audio/jfk.wav' to blah blah blah etc```?  Crude compared to running or serving the chat-centric models, but still adds value to Ramalama and also to Whisper (which has had [broken CUDA support](https://github.com/ggerganov/whisper.cpp/issues/2032#issuecomment-2078881661) for nine+ months and isn't as slick wrt pulling images and mounting volumes).

Also, should the container files be pulling the latest whisper.cpp instead of the latest known to be good for Ramalama?

I would say just this to start:

`ramalama --runtime whisper.cpp run ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin jfk.wav`

which would just perform a fairly standard whisper.cpp command.

No interactive support, it's not the same as a chat bot workflow.

We have renovate controlling what version of whisper.cpp we build against and it runs everything through CI before we rebase, I'd like to keep this, at least there's a CI run before we suddenly change version. Just cloning main/master without CI, I'd rather not.
@p5 kindly set up renovate for us.

> `ramalama --runtime run whisper.cpp ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin`
> 
> which would just perform a fairly standard whisper.cpp command.

Could you elaborate, please?  What command would be performed?  Would that be provided through additional command-line arguments to the command you've just given?  Would you pass that as though it were a prompt to another model?

The boilerplate syntax for using whisper.cpp directly is something like ```./main -m /models/ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin -f /audios/jfk.wav```  Could you please give me an example of the kind of command-line you're envisioning to complete the same task via Ramalama?  

> No interactive support, it's not the same as a chat bot workflow.

Sorry to be dense, but I can't tell if you're reiterating that whisper.cpp does not provide interactive support or if you're saying that you do not like the concept of dropping the user to a shell prompt with some workspace-like features.

I meant something like this, corrected:

`ramalama --runtime whisper.cpp run ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin jfk.wav`

> Sorry to be dense, but I can't tell if you're reiterating that whisper.cpp does not provide interactive support or if you're saying that you do not like the concept of dropping the user to a shell prompt with some workspace-like features.

We are always open to ideas. It's just less relevant with whisper.cpp, one doesn't speak to an interactive prompt. But if someone finds that useful for some reason, always happy to look at PRs, etc.

This PR is a perfect example of why we don't just clone main/master:

https://github.com/containers/ramalama/pull/474

Yes, failing each time whisper.cpp is updated is perhaps a better solution than blindly updating along with it.  Anyway, back to the meat of my question...  

> It's just less relevant with whisper.cpp, one doesn't speak to an interactive prompt. But if someone finds that useful for some reason, always happy to look at PRs, etc.

I don't care at all about that.  I just saw the seemingly abandoned whisper.cpp stub in the container and thought to make it usable.  It is not currently usable, right?  Do you care to see it made usable?

> Yes, failing each time whisper.cpp is updated is perhaps a better solution than blindly updating along with it. Anyway, back to the meat of my question...
> 
> > It's just less relevant with whisper.cpp, one doesn't speak to an interactive prompt. But if someone finds that useful for some reason, always happy to look at PRs, etc.
> 
> I don't care at all about that. I just saw the seemingly abandoned whisper.cpp stub in the container and thought to make it usable. It is not currently usable, right? Do you care to see it made usable?

Yup we sure do, this issue is open for someone to complete it :)

> this issue is open for someone to complete it :)

Great.  I'm just having trouble understanding what "complete it" means to you.  That's why I'm asking about the example command-lines you're envisioning.  

> The boilerplate syntax for using whisper.cpp directly is something like ./main -m /models/ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin -f /audios/jfk.wav Could you please give me an example of the kind of command-line you're envisioning to complete the same task via Ramalama?

> > this issue is open for someone to complete it :)
> 
> Great. I'm just having trouble understanding what "complete it" means to you. That's why I'm asking about the example command-lines you're envisioning.

We are open to ideas. Rome wasn't built in a day, one PR at a time.

> 
> > The boilerplate syntax for using whisper.cpp directly is something like ./main -m /models/ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin -f /audios/jfk.wav Could you please give me an example of the kind of command-line you're envisioning to complete the same task via Ramalama?

Getting this executing the main command you specified would be a start

ramalama --runtime whisper.cpp run ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin jfk.wav

Thanks.  And in the case that Ramalama is running the inferencing in a container, how we get the input media into the model?  Would you infer a directory to bind based on the working directory/file given as an argument?

Yes the wav file would need to be volume mounted into the container with a :z option.

Would it make sense to also allow stdin for a way file?

cat jfk.wav | ramalama --runtime whisper.cpp run ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin -

I think it makes sense to allow grab output from stdout.

cat jfk.wav | ramalama --runtime whisper.cpp run ggml-large-v3-turbo.bin - > /tmp/output

Not sure what ramalama serve would do?

Thank you for helping to bring me up to speed with some mock usage examples.  I'm still pretty novice at containers, but could we bind the directory read-only instead of using :z?  A dryrun (*love* that feature, btw) of something like(?):

        podman run --rm -i --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \
        --mount=type=image,src=WHISPER.CPP-MODEL-SHORTNAME,destination=/mnt/models,rw=false,subpath=/models \
        --mount=type=bind,src=/[FQual-dir-of-user-inputfilewav]/,destination=/mnt/audio,rw=false \
        ramalama-image /bin/sh -c "whisper-main -m /mnt/models/model.file -f /mnt/audio/USERFILE.wav"

> Would it make sense to also allow stdin for a way file?

It's more appealing in principle than binding directories, but whether or not it is practical is currently unknown to me.  It has been a verrrrry long time since I've relied on a shell to create pipes for large data and I don't quite remember what the gotchas were, but I'm thinking there were at least a few.  I know even less about what might happen trying to pipe potentially massive, uncompressed audio files into the container on STDIN.  

> I think it makes sense to allow grab output from stdout.

Redirects aren't adequate?

> Not sure what ramalama serve would do?

If the documentation on the whisper.cpp github is accurate, it seems like the provided web service is very basic.  All the examples are making requests via curl from the command-line.  I totally get it and that isn't criticism, but we're not talking about a convenient UI AFAICT.  I am aware that there exist some third-party front-ends, like https://github.com/litongjava/whisper-cpp-server + https://github.com/litongjava/listen-know-web, but I don't really know anything about them.

For me, personally, the most likely use-case for whisper.cpp is in generating subtitles for arbitrary videos (upon audio extracted w/ ffmpeg) or for transcribing and translating arbitrary audio sequences.  Command-line invocation over a bound directory seems adequate and possibly ideal.  It probably doesn't require any code overlap with whisper.cpp, using Ramalama as scaffolding to bring all the pieces together and offering a layer of abstraction wrt GPU config, system libraries, etc.  But I'm not deep into any of these techs or projects, so if there's a better vision / direction I'd love to hear about it.

The stdout stuff should just work, we could even just have whisper grab /dev/stdin when it sees the "-". 

The volume mount can also be marked ro,z so it is both readonly and available for reading based on SELinux.

podman run --rm -i --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \
    --mount=type=image,src=WHISPER.CPP-MODEL-SHORTNAME,destination=/mnt/models,rw=false,subpath=/models \
    --mount=type=bind,src=/[FQual-dir-of-user-inputfilewav]/,destination=/mnt/audio/USERFILE.wav,rw=false,z \
    ramalama-image /bin/sh -c "whisper-main -m /mnt/models/model.file -f /mnt/audio/USERFILE.wav"

Slightly simpler.

podman run --rm -i --device nvidia.com/gpu=all \
--mount=type=image,src=WHISPER.CPP-MODEL-SHORTNAME,destination=/mnt/models,rw=false,subpath=/models \
-v/[FQual-dir-of-user-inputfilewav]/:/mnt/audio/USERFILE.wav:ro,z \
ramalama-image /bin/sh -c "whisper-main -m /mnt/models/model.file -f /mnt/audio/USERFILE.wav"
Looks like `whisper -f -` is supported now, although the entire file needs to be flushed through the pipe I believe.

> Looks like whisper -f - is supported

It does look that way, though I haven't prepared any large wav files to test with.  Thank you - your way is much better, I think, than binding a directory for a process that will only require one input.  Especially if it creates the possibility of chaining ffmpeg without intermediate conversion files.

So, consensus seems to be that ```cat jfk.wav | ramalama --runtime whisper.cpp run ggml-tiny.bin``` should produce and run something vaguely like ```podman run --rm -i --device nvidia.com/gpu=all --mount=type=bind,src=models/,destination=/mnt/models,rw=false ramalama /bin/sh -c "whisper-main -m /mnt/models/ggml-tiny.bin -f -"```  That doesn't seem too difficult at first blush.  I'll see what I can do in the coming days.

Thanks

Hi all, just wanted to add a quick follow-up to this thread since I participated in the discussion.

At the time, my primary use case was generating subtitle files (e.g., SRT) for a side project. After our discussion, it became clear that the most direct path for Ramalama was to support piping `whisper.cpp`'s standard output, while my need was more centered around its file-based output features (like `-osrt`).

Since my project priorities were tied to that specific workflow, I ended up moving in a different direction and didn't have the bandwidth to circle back to implement the `stdin`/`stdout` plan we discussed. Apologies for not closing the loop sooner.

It's great to see the issue is still active and that you're still actively improving Ramalama.  It's a great and undervalued tool.

-FNG

issueDTO.title: Prefixed attributes are not detected as duplicated
issueDTO.description:
### Summary

Although the mechanism for checking inner meta items is present in the lint logic, it doesn't properly account for the fact that inner meta items will not have their name (which contains, e.g., `allow`, `deny`, etc.) set when recursing.

Found while working on #14855.

@rustbot label "+good first issue"

### Lint Name

`duplicated_attributes`

### Reproducer

I tried this code:

```rust
#![deny(unused, unused, clippy::duplicated_attributes, clippy::duplicated_attributes)]

fn main() {}
```

I expected to see this happen: two errors, one for the duplication of `#![deny(unused)]`, and one for the duplication of `#![deny(clippy::dupplicated_attributes)]`.

Instead, this happened:

Only the duplication of `#[deny(unused)]` is detected.

```txt
error: duplicated attribute
 --> /tmp/t.rs:1:17
  |
1 | #![deny(unused, unused, clippy::duplicated_attributes, clippy::duplicated_attributes)]
  |                 ^^^^^^
  |
note: first defined here
 --> /tmp/t.rs:1:9
  |
1 | #![deny(unused, unused, clippy::duplicated_attributes, clippy::duplicated_attributes)]
  |         ^^^^^^
help: remove this attribute
 --> /tmp/t.rs:1:17
  |
1 | #![deny(unused, unused, clippy::duplicated_attributes, clippy::duplicated_attributes)]
  |                 ^^^^^^
  = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#duplicated_attributes
note: the lint level is defined here
 --> /tmp/t.rs:1:56
  |
1 | #![deny(unused, unused, clippy::duplicated_attributes, clippy::duplicated_attributes)]
  |                                                        ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

error: aborting due to 1 previous error
```

### Version

```text
rustc 1.89.0-nightly (70b3f4666 2025-05-30)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 70b3f4666e24ce22fc32f5e357dbcf85d3254e63
commit-date: 2025-05-30
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.89.0-nightly
LLVM version: 20.1.5
```

issueDTO.title: includesAttrSelector: support different equality checks in attribute selectors too
issueDTO.description:
We have a helper function named `includesAttrSelector`. We use this to check if an attribute has been referenced in the stylesheet. If so, the plugin may have different behavior. Usually, by not removing that attribute because it may break styles otherwise.

However, our logic takes a very safe approach, of never deleting attributes if it's been referenced in CSS, even if the operator/check wouldn't match.

For example, suppose an element in an SVG had `preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet"`, with a CSS selector of `[preserveAspectRatio^="y"]`.

This would not match, yet to be on the safe side, we will not remove the attribute. We do not actually check the operator and value, but only the key. Let's improve the logic to actually perform these checks so that we do remove the attribute when it's truly unnecessary.

References:

* https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/Attribute_selectors#syntax

issueDTO.title: Add Caching for check_public_repo()
issueDTO.description:
Currently, the method `check_public_repo()` calls the GitHub API every time it is invoked. This results in redundant requests that can be optimized through caching. Implementing caching will improve performance and reduce the number of calls made to the GitHub API.

**Proposed Changes:**

1. **Implement Caching**:
   - Introduce a caching mechanism to store the visibility status of repositories after the first API call.
   - Use an in-memory caching solution like `cachetools` or utilize built-in Python caching decorators to manage the cache.
   - Ensure that the cache is valid for a reasonable time period or until the repository status changes.

2. **Modify `check_public_repo` Method**:
   - Refactor the existing `check_public_repo` method to first check the cache for the repository status before making the API call.
   - Update logic to cache the results from GitHub API calls.

3. **Testing**:
   - Write unit tests to verify that the caching mechanism works as intended and that subsequent calls to `check_public_repo()` use the cached data instead of hitting the GitHub API.

4. **Documentation**:
   - Update any relevant documentation to reflect these changes and ensure that the caching logic is well-understood for future developers.

**Impacted Files**:
- `app/modules/code_provider/github/github_service.py`: This is the primary file where the `check_public_repo` method is defined and updated.

**Next Steps**: If approved, I will begin implementing the caching mechanism and refactoring the `check_public_repo` method. Following that, a pull request will be submitted for code review.

issueDTO.title: Add support for automatic ICORE conference ranking lookup
issueDTO.description: ## Motivation The [ICORE (International CORE Conference Rankings)](https://www.core.edu.au/home) is a ranking of computer science conferences (A*, A, B, C). In JabRef, we want to add a new field that stores the ICORE ranking of a given conference. Users often want to know how highly ranked a paper's venue is. You can search conferences manually via the [ICORE website](https://portal.core.edu.au/conf-ranks/), but this should be automated. Example search result ## 📌 Goal When a BibTeX entry includes a conference title like: `ACIS Conference on Software Engineering Research, Management and Applications (SERA)` The tool should: - Extract the acronym in parentheses ??? SERA. - Search the ICORE rankings for this acronym. - If a match is found (e.g. SERA has rank C), populate the new icoreranking field with that value. - If no exact match is found, fall back to fuzzy matching using similarity scoring (> 0.9). ## 🛠??? Tasks - [ ] Move DuplicateCheck#similarity from org.jabref.logic.database to a new utility class: org.jabref.logic.util.strings.StringSimilarity. - [ ] Add ICORE.csv to src/main/resources/ - [ ] Create a class that loads and indexes the ICORE data at instantiation. - [ ] Implement the logic to detect and return the ranking from a full conference name. - [ ] Create a new field: ICORANKING ('icoranking') and add it to org.jabref.model.entry.field.StandardField at the // JabRef-specific fields section. - [ ] Create a new field editor ICoreRankingEditor (inspired by IdentifierEditor) and integrate it into the UI by modifying FieldEditors#getForField(...). - Tghe lookup button (like DOI lookup) to lookup the ranking in the `CSV` file - [ ] Write unit tests for acronym matching and similarity fallback. Test end-to-end behavior via TDD. ## 📚 Helpful resources [How to contribute to JabRef](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#contributing) [JabRef Developer Documentation](https://devdocs.jabref.org/) ICORE Rankings CSV: https://portal.core.edu.au/conf-ranks/ ??? Export CSV

issueDTO.title: Feature Request - Suppress & WhiteBox like feature in mockK
issueDTO.description:
- [x] I am running the latest 

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no 

- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed

#### Feature/Function Requests 

##### `Suppress unwanted behaviour`
I'm using the MockK library to write my kotlin android unit tests and it's really pain in my ass while writing unit tests for Android activity classes which have override methods like `onCreate()`, `onResume()`, `onNewIntent()` etc that call their parent classes. 

I'm looking for a feature in mockk with which i can suppress the parent class calls and complete my unit tests peacefully. Currently I've to write hybrid unit tests by using PowerMockito along with mockK library to use the [suppress functionality](https://github.com/powermock/powermock/wiki/Suppress-Unwanted-Behavior) provided by PowerMockito, due to lack of such cool feature or function in mockK.

#### `WhiteBox`
[WhiteBox](https://www.javadoc.io/doc/org.powermock/powermock-reflect/1.6.4/org/powermock/reflect/Whitebox.html) is another useful one from PowerMockito which is missing in mockK and would really be helpful if available on this library.

Current Specs:
* MockK version: V1.12.3 
* OS: Mac OS
* Kotlin version: 1.6.0

issueDTO.title: Default values for more [bundle] settings
issueDTO.description:
I'm currently bundling a macos desktop app, using as many default settings as possible.

I had the following in my `Dioxus.toml`:

```toml
[bundle.macos]
icon = "platform/macos/appicon.png"
```

The bundle failed with "missing field" `files` then subsequently `hardened_resource`. 

The dioxus `bundle.rs` contains:

```rust
#[derive(Debug, Clone, Serialize, Deserialize, Default)]
pub(crate) struct MacOsSettings {
    pub(crate) frameworks: Option<Vec<String>>,
    pub(crate) minimum_system_version: Option<String>,
    pub(crate) license: Option<String>,
    pub(crate) exception_domain: Option<String>,
    pub(crate) signing_identity: Option<String>,
    pub(crate) provider_short_name: Option<String>,
    pub(crate) entitlements: Option<String>,
    pub(crate) info_plist_path: Option<PathBuf>,
    /// List of custom files to add to the application bundle.
    /// Maps the path in the Contents directory in the app to the path of the file to include (relative to the current working directory).
    pub files: HashMap<PathBuf, PathBuf>,
    /// Preserve the hardened runtime version flag, see <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/security/hardened_runtime>
    ///
    /// Settings this to `false` is useful when using an ad-hoc signature, making it less strict.
    pub hardened_runtime: bool,
}
```

Questions:

1. Why aren't `files` and `hardened_runtime` optional?

2. Looking at the code, the same question applies to:
    - DebianSettings::files
    - WixSettings:: - various -
    - WindowsSettings::tsp & allow_downgrades
    - NsisSettings::display_language_selector

3. I only really want to provide the icon, thou it's `png` for linux & macos and an `ico` for windows.  Is there a common to specify the icon that is suitable for all platforms?

4. ~~A Discord conversation last night implied these (files & hardened_runtime) weren't documented, but I can see this morning that they are~~
comments: We should have defaults with `#[serde(default = "...")]` for the bundle fields where possible. The struct format is copied from the tauri bundler crate to make converting between them easier, but for deserialization we can use a default value if the key isn't present

Yes, defaults would be really helpful. Because setting an icon in `[bundle.windows]` forces you to set settings to things like `tsp`  where i don't really know what this is ??? or suddenly i need to decide what `webview_install_mode: WebviewInstallMode` i want to have where it worked just fine before i wanted to change the icon.

issueDTO.title: [Documentation]: Translation for documentation site
issueDTO.description: # Help translate me3.readthedocs.io **We have a Crowdin account at https://crowdin.com/project/me3. Contributions and machine translation reviews appreciated.** Analytics show a lot of people are relying on machine translations to view the documentation site to varying degrees of success. We should look at getting translations from external contributors where possible. Here's a screenshot of our top 25 regions from GA:
comments: Hi! I'd be happy to help translate the documentation into Polish. I'm also an aspiring Technical Writer currently building my portfolio, and I'd love to contribute. If needed, I can also assist with improving and maintaining the existing documentation.

Hey! Contributions and improvements are more than welcome :). I've added Polish as a target language to Crowdin: https://crowdin.com/project/me3/pl. You'd be the first person who isn't a core contributor to access this so if I need to do something to approve your access let me know.

Currently we don't generate the HTML for other languages, but I'll be setting that up later today so it can be previewed in PRs and translated live on the site.
It looks like everything is set, and no further approvals are needed.

FWIW, that 100% comes from auto-generated machine translations which need manual review/approval. Japanese and Russian looks to be fairly accurate based on feedback so far, but we don't have any feedback on the others.

If you think those results look good enough (see: https://crowdin.com/editor/me3/10/en-pl?view=comfortable&filter=basic&value=5) we can approve them all and mark them as translated.
Yes, I realised that as soon as I started reading it. Overall, it looks quite good so far, but I???ve already noticed a few parts that could be edited to sound more natural in Polish.
Could you grant me proofreader status so I can approve the reviewed and translated sections?
Yep, done!

summary.attemptedFixes: The issue is currently being addressed by adding Polish as a target language to Crowdin, and setting up the HTML generation for other languages so it can be previewed in PRs and translated live on the site.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to translating the documentation site, and it's currently relying on machine translations with varying degrees of success. The analytics show that a lot of people are relying on machine translations, and it's suggested to get translations from external contributors where possible.

issueDTO.title: Enable / Disable TPS - Start / Stop mining
issueDTO.description:
Following OSMU townhall #29 discussion 

It would be very useful to have the ability to enable/ disable the onboard TPS that feeds the asic. 

this would allow for mining to be commanded by an external source to start/ stop mining whilst keeping the ESP and AxeOs alive , so the user can maintain connectivity, stats, swarm etc. 

a use case scenario is the upcoming solarbit $0/khw project. Currently i will cut the entire power to the bitaxe but would be better to just instruct the bitaxe via the BAP port to stop mining when sun is down.. and start mining when sun is up. a cleaner way that killing the entire miner. 

Summary: 

1) API command to start stop TPS 
2) BAP port ability to accept such commands from external esp32 hardwired via 6pin BAP 
3) Not sure if possible: but if no mining is being conducted .. we dont need active cooling on the asic.. therefore is it possible when TPS is commanded to stop power to asic to also terminate power to the fan ? worst case pwm to minimum ? thinking how we could maximize energy efficiency by only running essentials on bitaxe to maintain heartbeat. fan running for no reason ruins the efficiency and limit wasted power.
comments:
I agree, having a API call to enable/disable the voltage regulator (where supported) would be fantastic.

The challenge here is re-initializing everything when ASIC power is turned back on.

+1
something i had in mind since long time, to controle the miner by home assistant ..  :o)

repository.description: A bitcoin ASIC miner for the ESP32

summary.main: Implement API command to enable/disable onboard TPS that feeds the ASIC, allowing external control of mining and maintaining ESP and AxeOs connectivity
summary.validationOrRequirement: API command to start/stop TPS, BAP port ability to accept commands from external ESP32, and consideration for energy efficiency by controlling ASIC power and fan
summary.attemptedFixes: re-initializing everything when ASIC power is turned back on
summary.otherNotes: API command to start/stop TPS, BAP port ability to accept commands from external ESP32, and consideration for energy efficiency by controlling ASIC power and fan
